thread.title: Things We Saw Today: Protests Against the #MuslimBan Grow
thread.title_full: Things We Saw Today: Protests Against the #MuslimBan Grow

author: Marykate Jasper
title: Things We Saw Today: Protests Against the #MuslimBan Grow
text:
Protests against Trump’s ban on refugees and immigrants from 7 Muslim-majority countries continued in force today in cities across the U.S. Many cities which held airport protests on Saturday night were back on the streets this Sunday, and other cities planned new airport protests. Among the protest sites was Dulles Airport, where Customs and Border Protection officials are reportedly violating a court order and refusing to speak to members of Congress.
While we rally at @Dulles_Airport , thousands assemble in DC against the #MuslimBan . Trump is unifying America– against Trump. pic.twitter.com/wAE6RgAeCw 
— Rep. Jamie Raskin (@RepRaskin) January 29, 2017 

NOW: Massive protest forming in Copley Square. Boston showing up to fight Trump’s #MuslimBan . #NoBanNoWall pic.twitter.com/fc99ytsM4N 
— Evan Greer (@evan_greer) January 29, 2017 

Amazing energy at lax! #RefugeesWelcome #NoBanNoWall #MuslimBan pic.twitter.com/0ueME24cTf 
— Grace Meng (@grace_meng) January 29, 2017 

Protests now at John Glenn International Airport in Columbus, Ohio. #MuslimBan pic.twitter.com/TLLWC7Ze5r 
— Mekka Don (@MekkaDonMusic) January 29, 2017 

This 50 Shades of Alien mashup combines two of my nightmares–chest-bursting aliens and consent-oblivious depictions of BDSM–into one grossness cocktail. Thanks again, internet! If you’re one of the millions of Americans who’d rather speculate about trailers than sports, then /Film has the Super Bowl preview for you . They break down which trailers will likely drop on Super Bowl Weekend, from Guardians of the Galaxy 2 to The Dark Tower . Ride-sharing just got even more political. During last night’s protests, Lyft announced a $1 million donation to the ACLU. Uber, on the other hand, got rid of surge pricing from JFK Airport while NYC taxi drivers were holding a strike in support of refugees. Many pointed out that Uber’s actions looked suspiciously like strike-breaking, and CEO Travis Kalanick’s lukewarm response to Trump’s refugee and immigrants bans didn’t help. A #DeleteUber campaign kicked up on Twitter. (Via The Hollywood Reporter ) (Image via Josh Farelie)
